results.title: An Interview with Wing Commander Peter Isaacson : Chairman of the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees (1983-2000)
results.creator_credit: Peter Isaacson and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: After returning from World War II, having served in the RAAF as a Pathfinder, Peter Isaacson was appointed a Shrine of Remembrance Trustee. He discusses his time at the Shrine, as Chairman of the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees and the role of the Shrine in helping Australians remember as well as teaching those who don’t remember the history of Australia at war.
results.title_for_label: An Interview with Wing Commander Peter Isaacson : Chairman of the Shrine of Remembrance Trustees (1983-2000)

results.title: An Interview with Wes Bailey
results.brief_description: With a vibrant sense of humour, Wes Bailey recounts his various postings as a signaller during World War II. Long hot days of being eaten alive by mozzies as well as the expected pleasures of fruit and vegetables have nothing on the most significant posting of Bailey’s career, as husband to fellow signaller Phil Bailey.

results.title: An Interview with Warwick N. Johanson
results.brief_description: After joining the Navy when he turned 17, one of the first lessons Warwick Johanson learnt was that if anything moved, you saluted it, if it stood still, you polished it. His home for over four years was aboard the flagship, the HMAS Australia, often a target for the formidable Japanese Kamakaze. Warwick also reflects on World War II and what it was like in Australia, when the country was actually in peril, almost unimaginable in this day and age.

results.title: An Interview with Valda Maskell and Alf
results.creator_credit: Alfred Maskell, Valda Maskell and ACMI
results.brief_description: Valda Maskell, with the assistance of her husband Alfred, gives a touching account of how their love for each other survived World War 2. Valda met Alfred in Bendigo and they managed to get engaged just before Alfred was despatched to Malaya to fight the Japanese. The story is mostly told from Valda’s perspective, how she joined the RAAF and worked there as a cook and how she spent three years working there, all the while knowing nothing of Alfred’s fate. On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

The story is mostly told from Valda’s perspective, how she joined the RAAF and worked there as a cook and how she spent three years working there, all the while knowing nothing of Alfred’s fate. On his return, Valda promptly went AWOL, married Alfred and shares with us the ups and downs of her life with a returned soldier, who was also a prisoner of war.

results.title: An Interview with Susan George
results.creator_credit: Mark Stiles, Mary Leggett and Freedom From Hunger
results.brief_description: Susan George, food economist and author of “How the other half dies” talks about food distribution in the world, reasons for starvation amongst third world peoples and the influence of the western world upon third world hunger problems.

results.title: An Interview with Stan Guilfoyle
results.brief_description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.

results.title: An Interview with Raymond Jungwirth
results.brief_description: Raymond Jungwirth wanted to fly a spitfire but was convinced to undergo observer training. Initially trained in Canada, Raymond was posted to Europe, where he spent most of World War II. Here he provides a heartfelt account of friends made and lost, the waste of human life and visiting Belsen after the war and the lasting impression that stayed with him even after he returned to Australia.
results.description: Raymond Jungwirth wanted to fly a spitfire but was convinced to undergo observer training. results.title: An Interview with Phil Bailey
results.brief_description: Phil Bailey was a telegrapher - one of a unique cohort of women who were trained in signalling by a forward-thinking female engineer. She has never forgotten morse code due to the wise words of her teacher.

results.title: An Interview with Peter Isaacson : pathfinder
results.creator_credit: Peter Isaacson and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Peter Isaacson tells his story of joining the Air Force in World War II and becoming part of the legendary Pathfinders. Peter also became famous for flying under the Sydney Harbour Bridge towards the end of World War II.
results.description: Peter Isaacson tells his story of joining the Air Force in World War II and becoming part of the legendary Pathfinders. Peter also became famous for flying under the Sydney Harbour Bridge towards the end of World War II.
